sponsor: EXC2052/1 Africa Multiple, DFG Project number 390713894

project.name: Multiplicity in Decision-Making of Africa’s Interacting Markets: The Functioning of Community Law, the Role of Market Participants and the Power of Regional Judges

citation: Wild, F., & Stadelmann, D. (2022). Coastal proximity and individual living standards: Econometric evidence from georeferenced household surveys in sub-Saharan Africa. Review of Development Economics, 26(4), 1883–1901. https://doi.org/10.1111/rode.12901

titleInfo.title: Coastal proximity and individual living standards: Econometric evidence from georeferenced household surveys in sub-Saharan Africa

affl: Center for Research in Economics, Management, and the Arts, Zurich, Switzerland (CREMA)

current: Faculty of Law, Business & Economics, University of Bayreuth

abstract: We investigate georeferenced household-level dataconsisting of up to 128,609 individuals living in 11,261 localities across 17 coastal sub-Saharan African countries over 20 years. We analyze the relevance of coastalproximity, measured by the geographic distance toharbors, as a predictor of individual economic livingstandards. Our results highlight the role of human capital, urbanization, and infrastructural endowments in explaining within-country differences in individual economic welfare.

sponsor: EXC2052/1 Africa Multiple, DFG Project number 390713894

project.name: Multiplicity in Decision-Making of Africa’s Interacting Markets: The Functioning of Community Law, the Role of Market Participants and the Power of Regional Judges

citation: Wild, F., & Stadelmann, D. (2022). Coastal Proximity and Individual Living Standards: Econometric Evidence from Geo-Referenced Household Surveys. CREMA Working Paper Series 2021-22, Center for Research in Economics, Management and the Arts (CREMA)

titleInfo.title: Coastal proximity and individual living standards: Econometric evidence from georeferenced household surveys in sub-Saharan Africa

affl: Center for Research in Economics, Management, and the Arts, Zurich, Switzerland (CREMA)

current: Faculty of Law, Business & Economics, University of Bayreuth

abstract: We investigate geo-referenced household-level data consisting of up to 206,896 individuals living in 21,826 localities across 28 sub-Saharan African countries over 20 years. We analyse the relevance of coastal proximity as a predictor of individual economic living standards. Our results highlight the role of human capital as well as infrastructural endowments in reconciling the large intra-national disparities in individual economic welfare.

titleInfo.title: The link between regional temperature and regional incomes: Econometric evidence with sub-national data

affl: Center for Research in Economics, Management, and the Arts, Zurich, Switzerland (CREMA)

current: Faculty of Law, Business & Economics, University of Bayreuth

abstract: We study the link between temperature and economic development at the sub-national level, employing cross-sectional data from two distinct sources. In contrast to much of the existing cross-country literature on the temperature–income relationship, our setting allows for the inclusion of country-fixed effects.
